a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes paint_remaining :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "paint_remaining 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. paint_remaining (Suc n) = paint_remaining n / 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. paint_remaining n > 1 \<longrightarrow> paint_remaining (Suc n) \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "paint_remaining n \<le> 1"
shows  "n = 8"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes paint_remaining :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "paint_remaining 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. paint_remaining (Suc n) = paint_remaining n / 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. paint_remaining n > 1 \<longrightarrow> paint_remaining (Suc n) \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "paint_remaining n \<le> 1"
shows  "n = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: You have a paint container with an initial volume of 225 square meters (15 * 15). After each day, the remaining paint in the container is reduced by half. On day $n$, the remaining paint is less than or equal to 1 square meter. How many days ($n$) will it take for the remaining paint to be less than or equal to 1 square meter? The final answer is 8 days.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "S 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. S (n + 1) = S n / 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. S n > 1 \<longrightarrow> S (n + 1) > 1"
shows  "S 8 \<le> 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "S 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. S (n + 1) = S n / 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. S n > 1 \<longrightarrow> S (n + 1) > 1"
shows  "S 8 \<le> 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A sequence $S(n)$ is defined recursively as follows: $S(0) = 15^2$ and $S(n+1) = \frac{S(n)}{2}$ for all non-negative integers $n$. Given that $S(n) > 1$ implies $S(n+1) > 1$, find the smallest value of $n$ for which $S(n) \leq 1$. The final answer is $n = 8$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes zeno_painting :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "zeno_painting 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. zeno_painting (Suc n) = zeno_painting n / 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. zeno_painting n > 1 \<longrightarrow> zeno_painting (Suc n) \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "zeno_painting n \<le> 1"
shows  "n = 8"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes zeno_painting :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "zeno_painting 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. zeno_painting (Suc n) = zeno_painting n / 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. zeno_painting n > 1 \<longrightarrow> zeno_painting (Suc n) \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "zeno_painting n \<le> 1"
shows  "n = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A painting initially has an area of 15 by 15 square units. With each successive step, the area of the painting is halved. Find the smallest number of steps, $n$, such that the area of the painting is less than or equal to 1 square unit. The final answer is 8.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes floor_size :: real
and days :: nat
and remaining :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "floor_size = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "remaining 0 = floor_size"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> remaining n = remaining (n - 1) / 2"
and h3 : "remaining days \<le> 1"
and h4 : "remaining (days - 1) > 1"
shows  "days = 8"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes floor_size :: real
and days :: nat
and remaining :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "floor_size = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "remaining 0 = floor_size"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> remaining n = remaining (n - 1) / 2"
and h3 : "remaining days \<le> 1"
and h4 : "remaining (days - 1) > 1"
shows  "days = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A square floor has a side length of 15 units. Each day, a worker paints half of the remaining unpainted area. After some days, the remaining unpainted area is less than or equal to 1 square unit, but on the previous day, it was greater than 1 square unit. How many days did it take for the worker to reach this point? The final answer is 8 days.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_area :: real
and unpainted_area :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "total_area = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "unpainted_area 0 = total_area"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. unpainted_area (Suc n) = (1/2) * unpainted_area n"
and h3 : "\<exists>n. unpainted_area n \<le> 1"
shows  "LEAST n. unpainted_area n \<le> 1 = 8"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_area :: real
and unpainted_area :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "total_area = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "unpainted_area 0 = total_area"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. unpainted_area (Suc n) = (1/2) * unpainted_area n"
and h3 : "\<exists>n. unpainted_area n \<le> 1"
shows  "LEAST n. unpainted_area n \<le> 1 = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A square has a total area of 15 by 15 units. At each step, half of the remaining unpainted area is painted. What is the least number of steps needed so that the unpainted area is less than or equal to 1 square unit? The final answer is 8.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes floor_area :: real
and daily_progress :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "floor_area = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. daily_progress n = floor_area / (2 ^ n)"
and h2 : "sum (daily_progress) {1..8} \<ge> floor_area - 1"
and h3 : "sum (daily_progress) {1..7} < floor_area - 1"
shows  "8 = (LEAST n. sum (daily_progress) {1..n} \<ge> floor_area - 1)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes floor_area :: real
and daily_progress :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "floor_area = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. daily_progress n = floor_area / (2 ^ n)"
and h2 : "sum (daily_progress) {1..8} \<ge> floor_area - 1"
and h3 : "sum (daily_progress) {1..7} < floor_area - 1"
shows  "8 = (LEAST n. sum (daily_progress) {1..n} \<ge> floor_area - 1)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A worker is painting a square floor with an area of 225 square units. The worker's daily progress is such that they paint half of the remaining unpainted area each day. Find the minimum number of days the worker needs to paint at least 224 square units of the floor. The final answer is 8 days.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes zeno_paint :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "zeno_paint 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. zeno_paint (Suc n) = 0.5 * zeno_paint n"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. zeno_paint n > 1 \<longrightarrow> zeno_paint (Suc n) > 1"
and h3 : "zeno_paint n \<le> 1"
shows  "n = 8"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes zeno_paint :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "zeno_paint 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. zeno_paint (Suc n) = 0.5 * zeno_paint n"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. zeno_paint n > 1 \<longrightarrow> zeno_paint (Suc n) > 1"
and h3 : "zeno_paint n \<le> 1"
shows  "n = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A painter starts by painting a square with an area of 15 square units. At each subsequent step, they paint a new square with an area equal to half the area of the square painted in the previous step. After a certain number of steps, the area of the square painted is less than or equal to 1 square unit, but the area of the square painted in the previous step is still greater than 1 square unit. How many steps has the painter taken? The final answer is 8.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes days :: nat and area_left :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "area_left 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> day. day > 0 \<longrightarrow> area_left day = area_left (day - 1) / 2"
and h2 : "area_left days \<le> 1"
and h3 : "\<forall> day < days. area_left day > 1"
shows  "days = 8"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes days :: nat and area_left :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "area_left 0 = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> day. day > 0 \<longrightarrow> area_left day = area_left (day - 1) / 2"
and h2 : "area_left days \<le> 1"
and h3 : "\<forall> day < days. area_left day > 1"
shows  "days = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A square has an initial area of 225 square units. Each day, the area of the square is reduced by half. Find the minimum number of days required for the area of the square to be less than or equal to 1 square unit. The final answer is 8 days.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes square_feet_remaining :: real
assumes h0 : "square_feet_remaining = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> day. day \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> square_feet_remaining = square_feet_remaining * (1/2)^(day-1)"
and h2 : "square_feet_remaining * (1/2)^(day-1) \<le> 1"
shows  "day = 8"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes square_feet_remaining :: real
assumes h0 : "square_feet_remaining = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall> day. day \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> square_feet_remaining = square_feet_remaining * (1/2)^(day-1)"
and h2 : "square_feet_remaining * (1/2)^(day-1) \<le> 1"
shows  "day = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A square lawn has an area of $15 \times 15$ square feet. Every day, exactly half of the remaining area of the lawn is mowed. After how many days will the remaining unmowed area be less than or equal to 1 square foot? The final answer is 8 days.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes days :: nat and floor_area :: real
assumes h0 : "floor_area = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n < days \<longrightarrow> floor_area * (1 / 2) ^ n > 1"
and h2 : "floor_area * (1 / 2) ^ days \<le> 1"
shows  "days = 8"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.
 The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
 \Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
 *)

theorem
fixes days :: nat and floor_area :: real
assumes h0 : "floor_area = 15 * 15"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n < days \<longrightarrow> floor_area * (1 / 2) ^ n > 1"
and h2 : "floor_area * (1 / 2) ^ days \<le> 1"
shows  "days = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A room has a floor area of 15 by 15 square units. Each day, the floor area of the room reduces to half of its size from the previous day. Find the number of days it takes for the floor area to be less than or equal to 1 square unit for the first time. The final answer is 8 days.

natural problem: Zeno had to paint a $15^\prime \times 15^\prime$ square floor. He decided that each day he would paint half of the unpainted part from the previous day until there was only one square foot or less left, in which case he would stay and finish the job that day. Using this strategy, how many days did it take Zeno to paint the entire floor?
natural solution: We focus on the portion of the floor that is left unpainted. After one day, $\frac12$ of the floor is left unpainted. After two days, $\frac1{2^2}$ of the floor is left unpainted, and so on. After $n$ days, $\frac1{2^n}$ of the floor is unpainted.

The floor has area $15^2 = 225$ square feet, so we look for the least number of days $n$ when at most $\frac1{225}$ of the floor is left unpainted: \begin{align} \frac1{2^n} &\leq \frac1{225}\\ \Rightarrow 2^n &\geq 225\\
\Rightarrow n&\geq8. \end{align} Thus, Zeno took $\boxed{8}$ days to paint the floor.
